across.text: Tailored coat mum’s altered, done without lining
across.explanation: CUSTOM-MADE(i.e. “tailored”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “altered”) of COAT MUM’S followed by DE (i.e. “done without lining”, i.e. the word “done” with its middle letters removed), like so: CUSTOMMA-DE.

across.text: What people pour into gardens with a cane and string for lashing
across.explanation: WATERING CANS(i.e. “what people pour into gardens”). Solution is W (a recognised abbreviation of “with”) and A followed by an anagram (indicated by “for lashing”) of CANE and STRING, like so: W-A-TERINGCANS.

across.text: Intimate audition for Court Theatre?
across.explanation: SHOW TRIAL(i.e. “court theatre”, playfully. A show trial is “a trial at which the opportunity to expose the accused to public opprobrium is given priority over the impartial prosecution of justice”(Chambers)). Solution is SHOW (i.e. to “intimate”) followed by TRIAL (i.e. “audition”).

across.text: Work at including queen in abstract piece
across.explanation: OP ART(i.e. “abstract piece”). Solution is OP (i.e. “work”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “opus”) followed by AT once wrapped around or “including” R (i.e. “queen”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of the LatinRegina), like so: OP-A(R)T.

across.text: Job involving a large American choir
across.explanation: CHORALE(i.e. “American choir”). Solution is CHORE (i.e. “job”) wrapped around or “involving” A and L (a recognised abbreviation of “large”), like so: CHOR(A-L)E.

across.text: Elected Conservative party scold head for lack of respect
across.explanation: INCONSIDERATENESS(i.e. “lack of respect”). Solution is IN (i.e. “elected”) followed by CON (short for “Conservatives”), then SIDE (i.e. team or “party”), then RATE (i.e. to “scold”) and NESS (i.e. “head”, in this case the geographical feature).

across.text: New York has speed and spirit
across.explanation: NYMPH(i.e. “spirit”). Solution is NY (a recognised abbreviation of “New York”) followed by MPH (i.e. “speed”, specifically Miles Per Hour).

across.text: Dog grips part of leg, exerting pressure
across.explanation: PUSHING(i.e. “exerting pressure”). Solution is PUG (i.e. “dog”) wrapped around or “gripping” SHIN (i.e. “part of leg”), like so: PU(SHIN)G.

across.text: Closed Civil Service during alarm
across.explanation: TOCSIN(i.e. an “alarm”). Solution is TO (i.e. “closed”, as in a door closed to) followed by CS (short for “Civil Service”) and IN (i.e. “during”). One nailed from the wordplay and a shufti in Chambers. It’s from the French, so you know what that means…

across.text: Wrong spring put into lock
across.explanation: TRESPASS(i.e. “wrong”). Solution is SPA (i.e. “spring”) “put into” TRESS (i.e. “lock” of hair), like so: TRES(SPA)S.

across.text: I am having beans? This will get one going
across.explanation: IMPULSE(i.e. “this will get one going”). Solution is I’M (a contraction of “I am”) followed by PULSE (i.e. “beans”).

across.text: Financially embarrass senator holding property
across.explanation: STRAITEN(i.e. “financially embarrass”). Solution is SEN (short for “senator”) wrapped around or “holding” TRAIT (i.e. attribute or “property”), like so: S(TRAIT)EN.

across.text: We should be away from fires
across.explanation: LET’S GO(i.e. “we should be away”). When written as LETS GO the solution also satisfies “fires” from a job.

across.text: They can up the tension to go round bends
across.explanation: TURNBUCKLES(i.e. “they can up the tension”). Solution is TURN (i.e. “to go round”) followed by BUCKLES (i.e. “bends”).

across.text: A stone? Queen and king, say, after millions for jewel in the crown
across.explanation: MASTERPIECE(i.e. “jewel in the crown”). Solution is A, ST (a recognised abbreviation of “stone”), ER (i.e. “queen”, specifically Elizabeth Regina) and PIECE (i.e. “king, say” – other chess pieces are available) all placed “after” M (a recognised abbreviation of “millions”), like so: M-(A-ST-ER-PIECE).

across.text: Kindly don outraged to be disturbed
across.explanation: GOOD-NATURED(i.e. “kindly”). “To be disturbed” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DON OUTRAGED.

across.text: Protest loudly about circuit crash
across.explanation: THUNDERCLAP(i.e. a “crash” of thunder). Solution is THUNDER (i.e. “protest loudly”) followed by C (i.e. “about”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “circa”) and LAP (i.e. “circuit”).

across.text: Extremely clever solver’s got this
across.explanation: EVER SO(i.e. “extremely”). “Got this” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: CL(EVER SO)LVER.

across.text: Annoying person is in touch
across.explanation: NUISANCE(i.e. “annoying person”). Solution is IS placed “in” NUANCE (i.e. “touch”), like so: NU(IS)ANCE.

across.text: Attach payment: a bit off Sunday roast?
across.explanation: SUBJOIN(i.e. “attach”). Solution is SUB (i.e. “payment”) followed by JOINT (i.e. “Sunday roast”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “a bit off”), like so: SUB-JOIN.

across.text: As some wild animals ate English lamb unfortunately
across.explanation: TAMEABLE(i.e. “as some wild animals are”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “unfortunately”) of ATE, E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) and LAMB.

across.text: Show off floor National Trust inlaid with gold
across.explanation: FLAUNT(i.e. “show off”). Solution is FL (a recognised abbreviation of “floor”) and NT (ditto “National Trust”) wrapped around or “inlaid with” AU (chemical symbol of “gold”), like so: FL-(AU)-NT.

across.text: Aperture in very large copper chimney up north
across.explanation: OSCULUM(i.e. “aperture”, specifically “an exhalant aperture in a sponge”(Chambers)). Solution is OS (i.e. “very large”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “outsize”) followed by CU (chemical symbol of “copper”) and LUM (i.e. “chimney up north”, a Scots word). One nailed from the wordplay, unsurprisingly.

across.text: Ruminant – I had three finally in compound
across.explanation: OXIDE(i.e. “compound”). Solution is OX (i.e. “ruminant”) followed by I’D (a contraction of “I had”) and E (i.e. “three finally”, i.e. the last letter of “three”).

across.text: Much action with bombers flying in which fuel catches fire
across.explanation: COMBUSTION CHAMBER(i.e. “in which fuel catches fire”). “Flying” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of MUCH ACTION and BOMBERS.

across.text: Underlying theme of message from HMS Vanguard?
across.explanation: SUBTEXT(i.e. “underlying theme”). When written as SUB TEXT the solution playfully satisfies the remainder of the clue, “HMS Vanguard” being a submarine and TEXT being an informal name for an SMS message.

across.text: Mend incomplete iron blade
across.explanation: KNIFE(i.e. “blade”). Solution is KNIT (i.e. “mend”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “incomplete”) and the remainder followed by FE (chemical symbol of “iron”), like so: KNI-FE.

across.text: Poisonous plant of the underworld Persephone finally brought forth
across.explanation: HELLEBORE(i.e. “poisonous plant”). Solution is HELL (i.e. “the underworld”) followed by E (i.e. “Persephone finally”, i.e. the last letter of “Persephone”) and BORE (i.e. “brought forth”). Another nailed from the wordplay. Nicely worked, though.

across.text: Walk in sounding weary, something unprepared players may do
across.explanation: SIGHT-READING(i.e. “something unprepared players may do”, being “someone who can read or perform music at first sight of the notes”(Chambers)). Solution is TREAD (i.e. “walk”) placed “in” SIGHING (i.e. “sounding weary”), like so: SIGH(TREAD)ING.

across.text: Crucial batsman’s actions – these could be character forming
across.explanation: KEYSTROKES(i.e. “these could be character forming”, as in typed characters on paper or a screen). Solution is KEY (i.e. “crucial”) followed by STROKES (i.e. “batsman’s actions” in cricket).

down.text: Specific example of something in milk and nought in beer?
down.explanation: CASE IN POINT(i.e. “specific example”). Solution is CASEIN (i.e. “something in milk”, a protein used in the production of cheese) followed by O (i.e. “nought”) once placed “in” PINT (i.e. “beer”), like so: CASEIN-P(O)INT.

down.text: Philosopher – one in short supply
down.explanation: STOIC(i.e. “philosopher” – a Stoic is “a disciple of the philosopher Zeno, who taught in theStoa Poikilē(Painted Porch) at Athens”(Chambers). It can also relate to said Stoics or their philosophy. Try as I might, I can’t twist any of this to make a “philosopher”. The clue seems to imply that disciples of a philosopher are philosophers themselves, which might explain why there are so many of them). Solution is I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) placed “in” STOCK (i.e. “supply”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “short”), like so: STO(I)C.

down.text: Endless game in old California lasting a number of years
down.explanation: OCTENNIAL(i.e. “lasting a number of years”, in this case eight). Solution is TENNIS (i.e. “game”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “endless”) and the remainder placed “in” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and CAL (ditto “California”), like so: O-C(TENNI)AL.

down.text: Intend to break pottery, causing damage
down.explanation: MAIMING(i.e. “causing damage”). Solution is AIM (i.e. “intend”) placed in or “breaking” MING (i.e. “pottery”), like so: M(AIM)ING.

down.text: United playing with learner, tending to reduce concentration
down.explanation: DILUENT(i.e. “tending to reduce concentration” of a substance). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “playing”) of UNITED and L (a recognised abbreviation of “learner”).

down.text: Trained medics aim to follow a constant and formal way of teaching
down.explanation: ACADEMICISM(i.e. “formal way of teaching”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “trained”) of MEDICS AIM placed after or “following” A and C (a recognised abbreviation of “constant”), like so: A-C-ADEMICISM.

down.text: Take selection from Keith? Eric? Keith or Eric?
down.explanation: EITHER(i.e. “Keith or Eric”, an inference that EITHER person would satisfy the first half of the clue. The riddly question mark at the end unnecessarily confuses things in my less-than-humble opinion). “Take selection from” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: K(EITH ER)IC.

down.text: Cutters in navy can inflict sinkings on raiding subs from the outset
down.explanation: INCISORS(i.e. teeth that are “cutters”). “From the outset” indicates the solution is derived from the initial letters ofInNavyCanInflictSinkingsOnRaidingSubs.

down.text: US park worker crushed small ring
down.explanation: GROUNDSKEEPER(i.e. “US park worker”). Solution is GROUND (i.e. “crushed”) followed by S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”) and KEEPER (i.e. a guard “ring” – I recalled this from a previous Jumbo).

down.text: Cell deficiency of a new blood group English intend going over
down.explanation: ANAEMIA(i.e. “cell deficiency”). Solution is A followed by N (a recognised abbreviation of “new”), then A (i.e. “blood group”), then E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) and AIM (i.e. “intend”) once the latter has been reversed (indicated by “going over”), like so: A-N-A-E-MIA.

down.text: Leave it on hospital round? Possibility for this?
down.explanation: STETHOSCOPE(i.e. “this” within the context of the clue, inferring a piece of medical equipment). Solution is STET (i.e. “leave it”, i.e. an editor’s note to ignore changes made and retain the original text, after the Latin for “let it stand”) followed by H (a recognised abbreviation of “hospital”), then O (i.e. “round”) and SCOPE (i.e. “possibility”). Very nicely worked.

down.text: Frank put on trousers as a means of expression
down.explanation: VOCAL CORDS(i.e. “a means of expression”). Solution is VOCAL (i.e. “frank”) followed by CORDS (i.e. “trousers”).

down.text: Great attitude to get on?
down.explanation: SUPERPOSE(i.e. “to get on” top of another). Solution is SUPER (i.e. “great”) followed by POSE (i.e. an assumed “attitude”).

down.text: Concerned with fool leading river rally
down.explanation: REASSURE(i.e. to “rally” another). Solution is RE (i.e. “concerned with” – think email replies) followed by ASS (i.e. “fool”) and URE (i.e. a “river”).

down.text: Nearly left somewhere without key in move
down.explanation: EXCITE(i.e. to “move”). Solution is EXITED (i.e. “left”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “nearly”) and the remainder wrapped around or placed “without” C (i.e. a musical “key”), like so: EX(C)ITE.

down.text: Notes one found in odd room with beds and lamps
down.explanation: SOLARIUM(i.e. “room with beds and [tanning] lamps”). Solution is SO and LA (both “notes” in the sol-fa notation) followed by I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) once placed “in” RUM (i.e. “odd”), like so: (SO-LA)-R(I)UM.

down.text: Cleaner reported to run off with fleece
down.explanation: STEEL WOOL(i.e. “cleaner”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “reported”) of STEAL (i.e. “run off with”) followed by WOOL (i.e. “fleece”).

down.text: Hollow rocks of granite, ovoid, excrescences on the outside
down.explanation: GEODES(i.e. “hollow rocks”). “On the outside” indicates the solution can be derived from the first and last letters ofGranitE,OvoiDandExcrescenceS.

down.text: Riverside’s gallery chaps need time for financial report
down.explanation: BANK STATEMENT(i.e. “financial report”). Solution is BANK’S (i.e. “riverside’s”) followed by TATE (i.e. London art “gallery”), then MEN (i.e. “chaps”) and T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”).

down.text: Pensions, perhaps, you once got in speculations
down.explanation: GUESTHOUSES(i.e. “pensions, perhaps” – a variant meaning of the word is a continental boarding house). Solution is THOU (i.e. “you once”, i.e. ye olde form of “you”) placed “in” GUESSES (i.e. “speculations”), like so: GUES(THOU)SES.

down.text: Maya chasing daughter is let down
down.explanation: DISILLUSION(i.e. “let down”). Solution is ILLUSION (i.e. “maya” – a new one on me) placed after or “chasing” D (a recognised abbreviation of “daughter”) and IS, like so: D-IS-(ILLUSION).

down.text: Dumb part of shoe done up like laces
down.explanation: TONGUE-TIED(i.e. struck “dumb”). Solution is TONGUE (i.e. “part of shoe”) followed by TIED (i.e. “done up like laces”).

down.text: Mammals, marine, wild – tons kept in enclosures
down.explanation: PINE MARTENS(i.e. “mammals”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “wild”) of MARINE and T (a recognised abbreviation of “tons”) all “kept in” PENS (i.e. “enclosures”), like so: P(INEMAR-T)ENS.

down.text: Raised youngster has the ability always to be a reckless adventurer
down.explanation: BUCCANEER(i.e. “reckless adventurer”). Solution is CUB (i.e. “youngster”) reversed (indicated by “raised” – this being a down clue) followed by CAN (i.e. “has the ability to”) and E’ER (i.e. poetic form of “always”), like so: BUC-CAN-E’ER.

down.text: British have no restraint in formal wear
down.explanation: BLACK TIE(i.e. “formal wear”). Solution is B (a recognised abbreviation of “British”) followed by LACK (i.e. “have no”) and TIE (i.e. “restraint”).

down.text: Post holder initially makes trouble over sack
down.explanation: MAILBAG(i.e. “post holder”). Solution is M (i.e. “initially makes”, i.e. the first letter of “makes”) followed by AIL (i.e. “trouble”) and BAG (i.e. “sack”).

down.text: Foot regularly started outside darts players’ mark
down.explanation: TROCHEE(i.e. “foot” in poetic terms. Again to Chambers: “a foot of two syllables, a long followed by a short”). Solution is TRE (i.e. “regularly started”, i.e. every other letter of STARTED) placed “outside” of OCHE (i.e. “darts players’ mark”), like so: TR(OCHE)E.

down.text: Hides from view round leader of crazy sects
down.explanation: OCCULTS(i.e. “hides from view”). Solution is O (i.e. “round”) followed by C (i.e. “leader of crazy”, i.e. the first letter of “crazy”) and CULTS (i.e. “sects”).

down.text: Fumed as a small donkey died
down.explanation: SMOKED(i.e. “fumed”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”) followed by MOKE (slang for a “donkey”, apparently) and D (a recognised abbreviation of “died”).

down.text: Stream runs inside reserve
down.explanation: BROOK(i.e. “stream”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “runs” used in a number of ball games) placed “inside” of BOOK (i.e. to “reserve”), like so: B(R)OOK.
